themes.title: Imperial Influence in Art
points: Discuss the role of imperial kilns during the Kangxi period in producing scholarly objects, emphasizing their connection to political power and cultural prestige.
Highlight how porcelain artifacts from the Qing dynasty reflect the values and priorities of the imperial court, tying this to the class subject of politics.
Engage students by asking them to consider how art can be used as a tool for political messaging or cultural dominance.

themes.title: Symbolism in Materials and Colors
points: Explain the significance of the white-green glaze on Southern Song dynasty porcelain, connecting it to the aesthetic preferences of the time and its subtle elegance.
Discuss the symbolism of 'red' in Chinese art and politics, tying it to themes of power, prosperity, and revolution.
Relate the use of clay and porcelain to the guide's cooking major by comparing the craftsmanship of ceramics to culinary techniques, emphasizing precision and transformation.

themes.title: Mythical and Cultural Narratives
points: Explore how mythical themes are often represented in Chinese art, asking students to identify any mythical motifs they see in the exhibit.
Discuss how myths and legends were used to reinforce imperial authority and cultural identity during the Yuan and Qing dynasties.
Encourage students to think critically about how political narratives are embedded in cultural artifacts, connecting this to their class subject.

themes.title: Interactive Engagement with Artifacts
points: Ask students to compare the Southern Song and Qing dynasty artifacts, focusing on differences in glaze, form, and purpose.
Encourage students to imagine themselves as artisans working in imperial kilnsâ€”what political pressures or artistic goals might they face?
Lead a discussion on how the materials (clay, porcelain) and techniques used in these artifacts reflect the technological advancements of their respective periods.
